Title: Contextual representations of negative images modulate intrusion frequency in an intrusion provocation paradigm

ResultSummary: Both conditions did not significantly in terms of lab intrusions.

Title: To think or not to think about trauma? an experimental investigation into unconscious thought and intrusion development
Author: Krans, Julie;Bos, Maarten W.
ExperimentalCondition: Unconscious thought (2-back working memory task + being told need film information)
ComparisonCondition: Control (2-back working memory task [being told the exp. has ended])
ResultSummary: Unconscious thought significantly reduced lab intrusions compared to distraction
Notes_fromMo: Intrusion content info Not Reported; Sample size info provided by author via email

Title: Wakeful rest compared to vigilance reduces intrusive but not deliberate memory for traumatic videos
Author: Horlyck, Lone D.; Bisby, James A.; King, John A.; Burgess, Neil
ResultSummary: Wake rest group showed lower intrusion frequency in intrusion provaction task than vigilence group

Title: I see what you're saying: intrusive images from listening to a traumatic verbal report
Author: Krans, Julie; Naring, Gerard; Holmes, Emily A.; Becker, Eni S.
ExperimentalCondition: Verbal interference task during encoding (articulatory suppression)
EncodingTask: Lisen to verbal report of trauma film
ResultSummary: No group difference on lab intrusion frequency immediate between verbal interference condition and no-task condition
Notes_fromMo: Contact Emily for sample size; sample size and trauma stimuli info provide by author via email
